text: Is there a general consensus around when unicode characters should be used? I tried to poke around the style guide and didn't see any recommendation.

elements.text: Is there a general consensus around when unicode characters should be used? I tried to poke around the style guide and didn't see any recommendation.

text:
There is a general consensus that one should not export a name with unicode chars unless there is an ASCII-only version also exported.  The idea is not to require all users to have various Unicode chars easily available (to read via a screen font or to type).

For using Unicode internal to your own functions / structures or in their names -- have at it.
Many people do this for some balance of clarity and terseness.

text:
Unicode is at its best when you can match textbook definitions from your field like `η` learning rates or `μ` means and such.  Also really good for subscripts like `x₀` starting points or slightly different versions of the same variable with primes `x′` and hats `x̂` and such.  Also really good for custom infix operators:

```julia> ⦿(x, y) = 2x+3y
⦿ (generic function with 1 method)

julia> 1 ⦿ 2
8```

text:
Thanks <@U6740K1SP>! Great examples! Is this considered a best practice, or is it more of a convenience for clarity? For example, if you're collaborating on an analysis or sharing a package, would these be encouraged?

For some background, I'm coming from the perspective of FDA clinical trial submissions and trying to understand whether ASCII would be acceptable for Julia programmers without having to compromise on best practices, or whether we should advocate for the FDA to accept unicode text programs. The other side of this coin is that unicode can make it easy to write obfuscated or misleading code, which the FDA might be wary of.
